input.description: XML document conforming to the ConnectionDetails Concept that contains the information required to execute a command.
Specifies the name or IP address of the remote computer. If no input is provided the information is provided for the local computer.

Runs the command with the account permissions of this specified User. The default is the permissions of the current logged-on user on the computer that issues the command. The input should contain the full name of the user in the form of "domain\username" e.g.
testdomain\testuser
The password of the user account that is specified in the run as user entry.
Specifies the user name whose RSOP data is to be displayed.
Displays either user or computer results. If the scope is ommited both user and computer settings will be returned. Valid values: user or computer.

output.description: XML document consisting of one or more <line> elements that contain the command response. Each <line> element contains an index attribute indicating the order in which the information was returned by the command.
Did the operation succeed? Valid values: true

xslt-stylesheet.stylesheet: <xsl:stylesheet xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform" version="1.0"> <xsl:output indent="yes" /> <xsl:template match="/"> <fat-command> <command os-id="Linux"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no">echo Command not supported on Linux.</xsl:text> </command> <command os-id="SunOS"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no">echo Command not supported on SunOS.</xsl:text> </command> <command os-id="Windows Default"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no">gpresult</xsl:text> <xsl:if test="string-length('${target computer}') != 0"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> /s ${target computer}</xsl:text> </xsl:if> <xsl:if test="string-length('${run as user}') != 0"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> /u ${run as user}</xsl:text> </xsl:if> <xsl:if test="string-length('${password}') != 0"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> /p ${password}</xsl:text> </xsl:if> <xsl:if test="string-length('${target user}') != 0"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> /user ${target user}</xsl:text> </xsl:if> <xsl:if test="string-length('${scope}') != 0 and '${scope}' = 'user'"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> /scope ${scope}</xsl:text> </xsl:if> <xsl:if test="string-length('${scope}') != 0 and '${scope}' = 'computer'"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> /scope ${scope}</xsl:text> </xsl:if> </command> <command os-id="Windows Server 2008"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no">gpresult</xsl:text> <xsl:if test="string-length('${target computer}') != 0"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> /s ${target computer}</xsl:text> </xsl:if> <xsl:if test="string-length('${run as user}') != 0"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> /u ${run as user}</xsl:text> </xsl:if> <xsl:if test="string-length('${password}') != 0"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> /p ${password}</xsl:text> </xsl:if> <xsl:if test="string-length('${target user}') != 0"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> /user ${target user}</xsl:text> </xsl:if> <xsl:if test="string-length('${scope}') != 0 and '${scope}' = 'user'"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> /scope ${scope} /v </xsl:text> </xsl:if> <xsl:if test="string-length('${scope}') != 0 and '${scope}' = 'computer'"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> /scope ${scope} /v </xsl:text> </xsl:if> </command> </fat-command> </xsl:template> </xsl:stylesheet>

documentation.description: Get Group Policy Displays Group Policy settings and Resultant Set of Policy (RSoP) for a user or a computer.
